author: jveer634
content:
Hi

What happens to the CL attestation during syncing state ?
For example, let's say I have just started up a new full node my node will be in syncing mode since I don't have any history saved. And from my understanding that the attestation process is time dependant and not any event dependant. It will automatically attest to the latest local view of its state.  So I am assuming it still participates in the attestation process. 

Am I assuming right ? Or it depends on the implementation of the CL client ?

author: sproul
content:
If your CL and EL are both synced to head, then they will attest. This is fairly universal across clients. They can still be downloading historic data, that's fine and won't block attesting.

However, if either CL or EL is still syncing forwards, then no attestations will be produced. The validator hasn't fully validated the state, so it is unsafe for them to attest to it.

author: sproul
content: What usually happens is the CL checkpoint syncs from the finalized checkpoint, syncs to head in a few minutes, and then waits for the EL to finish its snapshot sync (which takes longer because the EL state is vastly larger).

author: jveer634
content: So until both of them are in sync, no attestation occurs, right ?

author: jveer634
content: And also one more question is, what happens to the non elected forks ? I think they are called Uncle chains /blockcs in the PoW. Idk the exact term in PoS. <@602753420033785856>

author: sproul
content: Non-canonical forks, yeah. They exist for a maximum of 2 epochs usually until there's a new finalization which makes them permanently inviable, at which point most clients will prune them (delete the data forever). There's no reward in PoS for producing non-canonical blocks (no uncles)

author: jveer634
content: So the client invidividually decide when to delete them ? No standard way

author: sproul
content: All clients will stop processing blocks that descend from them once they conflict with finalization, that's part of the spec. Whether the non-canonical data is deleted completely or archived somewhere is client specific
